results.title: Australian diary. No. 122
results.brief_description: Magazine items: The Australian Consumers’ Association test on the durability of children’s shoes; a display in South Australia for prospective buyers and pilots of light aircraft; a dazzling exhibition by Horace lindrum, last of five generations of Lindrums, all of whom have proved masters on the billiard table.

results.title: Drinking driving surviving
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Alcohol plays an important part in our society as a relaxant and a status symbol, but when mixed with driving the results can be disastrous. This film explores the pressures to drink, the myths to which many Australians subscribe about drinking and driving, and the stark fact that alcohol, even in small amounts, seriously impairs driving

results.title: Rooftopics
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Joe Scully and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Views of Sydney Harbour, city and inner suburbs from the roof-tops of various buildings. Shows scenes of everyday activities, roof gardens, play-grounds, swimming pools, street traffic, etc. viewed from above. Includes humorous animated sequence involving a man, his towel and a woman beside a swimming pool. No spoken commentary. Edited by Wayne Le Clos; photographed by George Alexander; music by Eric Gross and script by Antonio Colacino.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 089
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: To painters and riggers working on Sydney’s Harbour Bridge walking on narrow girders high above the city is no different to walking down a suburban street; Bell Bay, Tasmania, is the site of the first complete aluminium smelter in the Southern hemisphere; Sydney’s Garrison Church provides a link with early pioneers; Australian Boy Scouts take part in the Eighth World Jamboree held at Niagara, Canada.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Australian [colour] diary. No. 040. The Vintage
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Frank Bagnall, Australian news and Information Bureau and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Reflects the growing industry of the Barossa Valley, in South Australia - one of Australia’s major wine producing areas. Settled by the Germans in the 1840’s, the valley has little towns of great charm. Around these early settlements, pioneers planted vines they had brought with them and many of their descendants continue to run family wineries. Photographed by Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Hannant, Frank Bagnall, Australian news and Information Bureau and Film Australia

results.title: Australian army at war 1939-1945 (Episode 2)
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War Experience”.
Uses actual newsreel footage to record the Australian soldier’s participation in the Second World War. Covers fighting in Libya, Greece, Crete, Syria and Tripoli, and the Singapore, New Guinea and Borneo campaigns.

results.title: Railways at work
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Transport in Australia”.
Shows the vital role of railways in Australia’s economy. Includes scenes from each state to illustrate rolling stock, services and people who depend on railways, directly or indirectly.

results.title: The Rail way
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Don Murray, Department of Transport and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A look at railways in Australia from Alice Springs to Kalgoorlie and Normanton. Shows trains serving the mining fields in central Queensland and the suburban trains of the big cities. Discusses problems brought about by different gauges throughout the country, and looks at the economic future of railways. Commentator Patsy Adam-Smith.

results.title: The Apprentice
results.creator_credit: Alan Harkness, Malcolm Otton, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Fontana Films
results.brief_description: Answers the questions of potential apprentices and their parents about how the apprenticeship scheme works in Australian industry by concentrating on Robert, an apprentice fitter and turner with an automotive firm. Robert, his father and his supervisor give their views on the training involved, which is intended to develop a boy’s character as well as to produce a good craftsman.
